# Multistage Transistors

![](darlington-pair-img/darlington-pair_1.png)

A Darlington pair is two transistors that act as a single transistor but with a much higher current gain\.

Thus\, a tiny amount of current from a sensor\, micro\-controller or similar can be used to drive a larger load\.

![](darlington-pair-img/darlington-pair_2.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

![](darlington-pair-img/darlington-pair_3.png)

The main feature of the Darlington connection is that the current gain is the product of the current gains of the individual transistors\.

![](darlington-pair-img/darlington-pair_4.png)

::: {.notes}

Explain the process as a self regulated system

:::

# Emitter Follower Configuration

![](darlington-pair-img/darlington-pair_5.png)

Impact of using the Darlington configuration is an  <span style="color:#ff0000">input impedance </span> much larger than that obtained with a single\-transistor network\.

The  <span style="color:#ff0000">current gain </span> is also larger\.

But the  <span style="color:#ff0000"> _voltage gain _ </span> for a single\-transistor or Darlington configuration remains slightly less than one\.
